columns.text: In the previous problem, we determined the value of our retirement account after 30 years if we deposit $475 monthly with 10% interest compounded monthly. In this exercise with the same scenario, we will determine the value of our retirement account after 30 years if we make an annual deposit of $5,700 instead.

In this exercise, we will consider the following details from the problem:

| Particulars                     |       |
|------------------------------------|-------|
| Interest rate (Compounded monhtly) | 10%   |
| Period                             | 30    |
| Annual payment                   | $475  |

Since the deposit is annual, we will first determine the effective annual rate or EAR. We will consider the EAR in calculating the future value of the investment.

The Effective Annual Rate refers to a loan's annual interest rate after considering the nominal interest rate and the compounding of periods.

The EAR calculation considers the APR and the compounding period of a loan. Hence, we will consider the annual percentage rate we calculated from the previous steps. The EAR can be calculated using the following equation:

$$ \begin{aligned}
\text{EAR} &=\left(1+\dfrac{APR}{m}\right)^m-1
\end{aligned}$$

Where:

$EAR$, which means the effective annual rate\
$APR$, which refers to the annual percentage rate\
$m$, which refers to the compounding period

In calculating the effective annual rate, we will consider the stated rate or APR of 10% and since its compounded monthly, the period we will use is 12 representing the number of months in a year. Hence, we will consider the following:

| Particulars                     |       |
|------------------------------------|-------|
| Rate (Compounded monthly) | 10%   |
| Compounding period                             | 12    |

Let's now calculate the effective annual rate.

$$ \begin{aligned}
\text{EAR} &=\left(1+\dfrac{0.10}{12}\right)^{12}-1
\\[10pt]
 &=\left(1+0.00833
\right)^{12}-1
\\[5pt]
 &=1.00833^{12}-1
\\[5pt]
&= \boxed{\bf{10.47\%}}
\end{aligned}$$

**As can be seen in our calculation, the effective annual rate is 10.47%.**

Next, consider the EAR from the previous calculation as the rate in determining the future value.

The future value is the value of a cash flow at a future date. The future value considers the present value of the cash flow multiplied by the factor of the rate and period.

In calculating the future value, we will use the spreadsheet function FV. 

The FV function determines the future value of an investment founded on constant payments interest rate and period. It is calculated on the spreadsheet using the following formula:

$$\begin{aligned}
NV&=(rate, nper,pmt,[pv],[type]) \\
\end{aligned}$$

Where:

$rate$, which refers to the interest rate\
$nper$, represent the period\
$pmt$, which means the constant payment\
$[pv]$, which refers to the present value\
$[type]$, which indicates the period basis of the computation

In calculating the future value in the spreadsheet, we will consider the following details:
| Particulars                     |       |
|------------------------------------|-------|
| Rate  | 10.47%   |
| Period                             | 30    |
| Annual payment                   | $5,700  |


Note that the payment value should be negative for the function to work correctly. The PV is zero since there are no present values provided, and the type is also zero since it's on a year-end basis.

Let's now calculate the future value.

!['slader'](https://slader-solution-uploads.s3.amazonaws.com/a4e1a505-0f0c-4a31-9df8-33f3ab6eb9c6-1641825079382600.png)
 

**Therefore, if we make an annual deposit of $5,700, the future value of our retirement account is $1,025,148.59.**
To conclude, we determined the future value by calculating the effective annual rate of the yearly deposit and considering it as the rate in the computation of the future valiue
